thread.title_full: Jobbatical website connects people with startup work abroad

author: Angela Swartz
title: Jobbatical website connects people with startup work abroad
text:
Comments 
For Ona Canilao , being grounded in the San Francisco Bay Area for work isn’t too appealing. 
That’s why the 37-year-old designer, who originally hails from the Philippines, joined the work sabbaticals site Jobbatical in June, becoming its 10,000th user after joining. The marketplace has postings like a one-year position for a regional digital marketing specialist in Singapore, and a three-month business development job in Düsseldorf, Germany. 
After she worked in public relations for several years, the recession hit. Out of a job, Canilao left the Bay Area for Paris, where she attended Ecole d'Art Maryse Eloy and studied graphic design for two years. See Also PowerToFly announces $6.5M in funding to get more women jobs 
“It was a good experience because I got to experience Paris Fashion Week and the Cannes Film Festival; I still can’t believe I got to do those things,” she said. “It was a different experience being able to meet a bunch of filmmakers and directors.” 
She returned to the United States in September of last year and has been job searching and doing graphic design projects here and there, along with volunteer work. 
“I knew I wanted to be able to work abroad again,” she said. “When I saw [Jobbatical] I was thinking, ‘Oh wow this is great.’ It shows that there are these really good positions everywhere in the world, and you don’t have to just be based locally.” 
The Estonia-based Jobbatical launched eight months ago and sets people up with short-term work adventures at startups around the world. It has raised about $329,200 to date, according to Crunchbase . There are about 250 live opportunities on the site at the moment. Page
